questions.text: A nulliparous woman presented with 26 weeks of gestation for routine antenatal check-up. Her blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. What can be the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine dipstick

 

  • A pregnant woman with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation should be evaluated for gestational hypertension or Pre-eclampsia.
  • So, the next step should be looking out for proteinuria by Urine dipstick test.  (Here Proteinuria refers to urine dipstick greater than or equal to +2 (1 gm/L) on at least two random clean catch samples   or a  total 24 hour urine protein > 0.3 gm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Uric Acid: Blood changes in pre-eclampsia may not be very specific however a serum Uric acid of more than 4.5 mg/dl may be considered as a biochemical marker

 

Option B. Liver Function tests and Option C. Complete blood count: LFTs may be raised and there may altered coagulation profile and thrombocytopenia

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation, the next best step is to evaluate for proteinuria using a urine dipstick test to screen for pre-eclampsia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics page 256, 262

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta previa: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marginal

 

Given image shows a Type 2 / Marginal Placenta Previa.

 

Other Options A, C, D are explained in the table below

 

OLDER CLASSIFICATION (BROWNE’S CLASSIFICATION)

 

 

 

NEWER CLASSIFICATION (BASED ON TRANSVAGINALSONOGRAPHY)

 

  1. Placenta Previa: Placenta partially or completely covers the internal os.
  2. Low lying placenta: implantation in the lower uterine segment is such that the placental edge does not reach the internal os and remains outside a 2-cm wide perimeter around the os.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low lying: Type 1 / Low Lying Placenta Previa is when the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment of the uterus but stays away from the internal os.

 

Option C. Incomplete: Type 3 / Incomplete Placenta Previa is when the placenta covers the internal os partially.

 

Option D. Complete: Type 4 / Complete Placenta Previa is when the placenta completely covers the internal os.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marginal Placenta Previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the margin of the internal os but not covering it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284, Williams textbook of Obstetrics  24th edition page 800

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented the following finding in the US. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged.
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
  • Theca lutein cysts are enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy
  • PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, in view of the history, OHSS is a more appropriate answer
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space. 
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections. 
    • Bilateral ovaries are enlarged and show presence of multiple follicular cysts
    • The OHSS risk is high in women with PCOS with high AMH, high AFC Or with history of previous high response.
    • Risk can be reduced using antagonist protocol with GnRH agonist trigger.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins is stopped in that cycle. 
    • Severe OHSS can also cause ascites, pleural effusion, liver dysfunction, raised hematocrit (>55%), oliguria, thromboembolic phenomenon etc. and must be managed conservatively.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: They may be seen in gestational trophoblastic diseases such as molar pregnancies. They subside once the HCG normalizes.

 

Option C. PCOS: It is characterized by the presence of 2 out of 3 criteria (Rotterdam criteria))

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts, increased capillary permeability, and leakage of intravascular fluid into the third space, commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH, or HCG injections, particularly in women undergoing controlled ovarian hyperstimulation for IVF.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition pg  529 Williams textbook of gynaecology 3rd edition pg 453

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to you with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal os

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of placenta previa which is caused due to placental implantation at the internal os.
  • Although the term placenta previa is diagnosed after 28 weeks, it can present with profuse bleeding at earlier gestational ages also.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: This will not present as profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks. This will present at a much earlier gestational age (6-8 weeks) and presents with abdominal pain (ruptured ectopic), vaginal bleeding (not profuse) and amenorrhoea (6-8 weeks)

 

Option C. Ovarian: Presents like an ectopic in the fallopian tube

 

Option D. Abdominal: This has varied presentations, but doesn’t present with profuse vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental implantation at the internal os, causing placenta previa, can lead to profuse vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 657, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • Points in favor of abruption
    • Abdominal pain
    • Pallor
    • High BP 
    • Uterine height > POG

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: In placenta previa, the bleeding is painless

 

Option C. Hydramnios: In hydramnios, there won’t be vaginal bleeding

 

Option D. Preterm labor: In preterm labor also there won’t be vaginal bleeding

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abruptio placenta is characterized by abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal movements, often associated with hypertensive disorders in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 295-297

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a previous cesarean section now presents at term. Which of the following is most favorable for a vaginal birth? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Previous lower segment cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

The type of uterine incision from a previous cesarean section significantly impacts the safety and likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).

 

The lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) involves a transverse incision made in the lower, thinner part of the uterus. This type of incision is most favorable for a vaginal birth due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor, which is around 0.2%.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Incision Types and Associated Risks:

 

Option A. Previous upper segment cesarean: This is also known as a classical cesarean section, where the incision is made vertically in the thicker, upper part of the uterus. The risk of uterine rupture with this type of incision is significantly higher, ranging from 4-9%.

 

Option C. Previous J-shaped cesarean: This incision extends from the lower segment into the upper segment, increasing the risk of rupture to 4-9%.

 

Option D. Previous T-shaped cesarean: This incision combines a lower segment transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper segment, also associated with a 4-9% risk of rupture.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most favorable incision for a vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is the lower segment transverse incision due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor.

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.

 

Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:

 

Angiogenic Factors:

 

  • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased
    • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
    • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • Factors that are decreased are
    • PlGF
    • PAPP-A
    • VEGF

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).

 

Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A G2P1L1 lady underwent LSCS in previous pregnancy for fetal distress. This time she had an uneventful vaginal birth after caesarean section (VBAC) but the placenta could not be removed completely. The cord snapped on traction, but the placenta did not deliver. She also started to bleed more profusely now. What is the likely reason for this? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta Percreta

 

  • This is a scenario of an adherent placenta
  • Adherent placentas can be
    • Simple adherent: can be removed by manual removal of placenta
    • Morbidly adherent
      • Should be suspected whenever there is a history of previous cesarean with retained placenta
      • Treatment: Urgent hysterectomy

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio Placenta: This presents as ante partum hemorrhage (painful vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks)

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This presents as antepartum hemorrhage due to a low lying placenta (Presents as painless vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks)

 

Option C. Uterine rupture: This presents as shock with vaginal bleeding with sudden cessation of uterine contractions usually in a patient with a prior cesarean section undergoing a trial of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morbidly adherent placenta, such as placenta percreta, should be suspected in cases of retained placenta with a history of previous cesarean section, and it often requires urgent hysterectomy to manage severe hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 484, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Antepartum hemorrhage due to abruption shows all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painless vaginal bleeding

 

Explanation:

 

  • Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. It is a characteristic feature of placenta previa.
  • Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.
  • Abruptio placenta is the partial or total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to bleeding and other complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Uterine tenderness: This is a common feature of placental abruption due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.

 

Option B. Frequent contractions: Increased frequency of uterine contractions is associated with placental abruption.

 

Option D. Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding: Vaginal bleeding of varying degrees, from mild to severe, is typically seen in placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental abruption presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions, but not with painless vaginal bleeding, which is characteristic of placenta previa.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1944,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 297

choices.text: Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent OGTT (75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours glucose at 180 mg/dI. Which of the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Admit and start insulin

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) as her OGTT results exceed the normal ranges.
  • The diagnostic criteria for GDM with a 75 g OGTT are:
    • Fasting glucose: ≥92 mg/dl
    • 1-hour glucose: ≥180 mg/dl
    • 2-hour glucose: ≥153 mg/dl
  • Given her fasting glucose level of 110 mg/dl and 2-hour glucose of 180 mg/dl, her levels are significantly elevated, indicating the need for medical management.
  • Insulin is preferred over oral hypoglycemics (OHAs) in this scenario due to the elevated fasting glucose level.
  • The initial insulin dose is typically divided and ranges from 0.7 to 1 unit/kg/day, often using a combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral hypoglycemics: OHAs are not the first choice in this scenario due to the elevated fasting glucose levels. Insulin is preferred for better control.

 

Option B. Reassurance: Reassurance alone is inappropriate as the patient has gestational diabetes requiring intervention to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia: Immediate induction of labour is not indicated solely based on the diagnosis of gestational diabetes at this stage. Proper management with insulin and monitoring is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of gestational diabetes mellitus, especially with elevated fasting glucose levels, insulin is the preferred treatment to achieve optimal glycemic control and prevent complications.

 

Ref: Page no 2783, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

choices.text: Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

choices.text: 1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 4 only

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Ultrasonography
  2. MRI
  3. Angiography
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation:


Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

  • Ultrasonography (1): This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • MRI (2): MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • Angiography (3): While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • X-ray (4): X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

Option C: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.

 

Option D: Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

 

Explanation:


For fetal lung maturity, dexamethasone is administered to help reduce the risks associated with premature birth by promoting the development of the fetal lungs. The recommended regimen for dexamethasone is:

 

  • 4 doses of 6 mg each administered intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

This dosing schedule is intended to maximize the benefit of corticosteroids in promoting fetal lung maturity and reducing the incidence of complications associated with preterm birth, such as respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, and the need for ventilatory support.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. This dosing regimen is not the standard for dexamethasone. The correct regimen involves 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option B. 2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart: Incorrect. This regimen is used for betamethasone, not dexamethasone. The standard for dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option D. 4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. The correct dosing for dexamethasone is 6 mg per dose, not 12 mg.

 

Educational Objective:


For fetal lung maturity, the recommended dose of dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg given intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

Ref: Page no 2088, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warning bleeds

 

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, either over or close to the internal cervical os. Key features of placenta previa include:

 

  • Warning bleeds: Also known as sentinel bleeds, are sudden-onset, recurrent, painless vaginal bleeding episodes that typically begin in the third trimester or during labor.
  • Soft, non-tender uterus: The abdominal examination reveals a soft and non-tender uterus, with the fundal height proportionate to the gestational age.
  • Normal fetal heart rate: The fetal heart rate is usually normal unless there is severe bleeding due to a large separation.
  • Malpresentations are common: Due to the lower placement of the placenta.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via transabdominal sonography or transvaginal sonography, which is safe and more accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark painful bleeding: This is characteristic of placental abruption, not placenta previa. Placental abruption presents with painful, dark vaginal bleeding due to the premature separation of the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine tenderness: Uterine tenderness is also a feature of placental abruption, where the uterus becomes firm and tender due to bleeding and clot formation behind the placenta.

 

Option D. Increased large uterine size: This is not a specific feature of placenta previa. Uterine size in placenta previa is proportionate to the gestational age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa typically presents with painless, recurrent vaginal bleeding (warning bleeds) in the third trimester or during labor, with a soft, non-tender uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1940, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 307

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration 

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.

 

Option C. Syphilis: A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 926

questions.text: A 25 yr G2P1 presents with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks. On examination, there is hypotension. The abdomen is tender and fetal parts not palpable. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a 25-year-old G2P1 woman presenting with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, several key clinical features point towards a diagnosis of abruptio placenta.

 

Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely, leading to significant bleeding.

 

The critical signs here are:

 

  • Hypotension: This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption.
  • Tender abdomen: The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta.
  • Fetal parts not palpable: This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.

 

Abruptio placenta - Immediate management (delivery) is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

In contrast, placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding, and the uterus is usually relaxed and non-tender. Placenta previa involves the placenta covering the cervical os, which can lead to painless bleeding without the tenderness seen in placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Usually presents with painless bleeding and a relaxed, non-tender uterus.

 

Option C. Show: Refers to the passage of a small amount of blood or mucus plug as labor begins, which does not cause significant bleeding or abdominal tenderness.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: While it can cause significant bleeding and abdominal tenderness, it is less common and typically associated with a history of uterine surgery or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding in Pregnancy after 28 weeks à is due to APH

 

2 MC causes are of APH are – Placenta Previa (Painless bleeding, nontender uterus) and Abruptio placenta (Painful bleeding, tense & tender uterus)

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows placenta previa.

 

The grades of placenta previa are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Type I (Low-lying): A major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • ﻿﻿Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it. This can be anterior or posterior
  • ﻿﻿Type III (Incomplete or partial central: The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • ﻿﻿Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasa previa: Blood vessels traversing through membranes overlying the internal os in front of the presenting part may be present in a velamentous placenta. Bleeding occurring due to rupture of membranes in such a case is of fetal origin.

 

Option C. Placenta accreta: It is a form of adherent placenta where placenta is directly adherent to myometrium.

 

Option D. Abruptio placenta: It refers to premature separation of a normally situated placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower segment of the uterus, partially or completely covering the cervix, which can lead to complications such as bleeding during pregnancy and delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

 

The correct answer is MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic). The classification of twin pregnancies is based on the timing of the zygote's division and the resulting structures, such as the number of chorions (placentas) and amnions (amniotic sacs) that form.

 

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins occur when the division happens very early (within the first 72 hours after fertilization), resulting in two separate chorions and amnions.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA) twins occur when the division happens between the 4th and 8th day after fertilization, after the chorion has formed but before the amniotic sac has split.
  • Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins result from division that occurs between the 9th and 12th day after fertilization, after both the chorion and amnion have formed, leading to two embryos sharing a single amniotic sac and a single chorion.
  • Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible scenario. The formation of a single amnion with two separate chorions (placentas) does not occur because the chorion forms before the amnion. Thus, this combination is anatomically and developmentally impossible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. MCMA (Monochorionic Monoamniotic): This is a recognized type of twin pregnancy where twins share both the chorion and the amnion.

 

Option B. MCDA (Monochorionic Diamniotic): Another recognized type, where twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. DADC (Dichorionic Diamniotic): This is the most common type of twin pregnancy, especially in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, where each twin has its own chorion and amnion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

choices.text: Emergency cesarean facility should be there

questions.text: Correct about trial of labor in a previous LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency cesarean facility should be there

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there. When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Emergency cesarean facility: The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%: This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.

 

Additional Considerations for TOLAC:

 

  1. Interval between pregnancies: The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar.
  2. Reason for previous cesarean: Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications.
  3. Monitoring: Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), ensure that an emergency cesarean facility is available to handle any complications, particularly the risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

questions.text: Which of the following can be expected if division of zygote occurs between 8 – 12 days after fertilization? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic Monoamniotic

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dichorionic Diamniotic: Occurs when the division of the zygote happens within the first 3 days after fertilization.

 

Option B. Dichorionic Monoamniotic: This is not a typical classification in twin pregnancies.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: Result from the division of the zygote occurring after the 13th day of fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins result from the division of the zygote occurring between 8 to 12 days after fertilization.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 24th edition page 893

questions.text: A chorionic villous sampling is done at 12 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive. What is the dose of Anti D given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of Rh incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative (B negative) and the father is Rh-positive (A positive), there is a risk of fetal-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) during invasive procedures like chorionic villous sampling (CVS). This can lead to the mixing of fetal and maternal blood, potentially causing the mother to form antibodies against the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. To prevent this alloimmunization, an Anti-D immunoglobulin injection is administered.

 

The standard practice is to give Anti-D immunoglobulin during any inciting event (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, abdominal trauma, abruption, placenta previa) and at delivery. Additionally, it is given prophylactically at 28 weeks of gestation to all Rh-negative women.

 

The dosage of Anti-D depends on the gestational age:

 

 

Less than 12 weeks: 50 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

More than 12 weeks: 300 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

Since the CVS was performed at 12 weeks, the appropriate dose of Anti-D is 50 micrograms.

 

Educational objective:

 

For Rh-negative women undergoing an inciting event like chorionic villous sampling at less than 12 weeks gestation, the dose of Anti-D given is 50 micrograms.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive of choice in a 28-week preeclamptic woman with asthma? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Explanation:

 

In managing preeclampsia, labetalol is often the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy. However, labetalol is both an alpha and beta-blocker, and its use can exacerbate asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Therefore, it is contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Nifedipine: This is a calcium channel blocker that is safe and effective in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of labetalol, making it the antihypertensive of choice for a preeclamptic woman with asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral labetalol and Option B. IV labetalol: Both forms are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: This angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause fetal renal hypoperfusion and oligohydramnios, among other teratogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine is the antihypertensive of choice in a preeclamptic woman with asthma due to its safety profile and lack of broncho constrictive effects.

questions.text: A 12 weeks pregnant lady visited the doctor. On ultrasound, it was found she has a low-lying placenta. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat ultrasound at 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

At 12 weeks gestation, the presence of a low-lying placenta is often not a cause for immediate concern because the placenta typically "migrates" upward as the pregnancy progresses. This migration is due to the expansion of the uterus, which effectively moves the placenta away from the cervix. Therefore, the recommended management is to repeat an ultrasound between 28 to 32 weeks to reassess the position of the placenta. By this time, the majority of placentas that were initially low-lying will have moved to a safer position, allowing for a more accurate determination of whether there will be any complications related to placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step for a pregnant woman found to have a low-lying placenta at 12 weeks is to repeat the ultrasound at around 32 weeks to reassess the placenta's position and determine appropriate management.

questions.text: Choose the best option to define a post-term neonate: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Born after 42 weeks of gestation

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Based on the above table

 

Option A. Born after 37 weeks of gestation:  early term (37 to 38 6/7  )

 

Option B. Born after 40 weeks of gestation: Late term between 41 to 41 6/7 and  Full term: between 39 to 40 6/7  and

 

Option D. Born between 37 – 40 weeks of gestation: Term pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter on preterm labor

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management? (FMGE DEC 2021)

 

Complete blood count

 

  • ﻿﻿Hemoglobin: 11g/dL
  • ﻿﻿Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/uL
  • ﻿﻿Platelets: 150,000 cells/uL

 

Liver function tests

 

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L
  • ﻿﻿Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L

 

Urinalysis

 

  • Protein: negative
  • ﻿﻿Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
  • ﻿﻿Bacteria: none

 

USG Abdomen:

 

Reveals a 7mm diameter, peristaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Do appendicectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy is the next stage of treatment at the earliest. It is possible to do a laparoscopic appendectomy before 28 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The most frequent surgical, non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy is acute appendicitis.
  • Whenever acute appendicitis is suspected, it is better to operate since perforation and peritonitis can result in significant maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.
  • While performing laparoscopy, the position of trocars, type of entry, and rate of CO2 insufflation need to be adjusted due to the gravid uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait till 2nd trimester: This is not recommended as delaying surgery can lead to complications such as perforation and peritonitis, which can significantly increase maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Conservative management is not advisable in cases of suspected acute appendicitis during pregnancy due to the high risk of complications.

 

Option D. Reassurance: Reassurance is not appropriate in this scenario as acute appendicitis requires surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with suspected acute appendicitis, prompt surgical intervention, preferably a laparoscopic appendectomy, is recommended to avoid complications.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 1079,

928, Duttas textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 355

choices.text: Red degeneration of fibroid
Torsion of fibroid
None of the above

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid 

 

Explanation:

 

Red degeneration- occurs mostly in pregnancy. Due to thrombosis of capsular veins.

 

  • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever.
  • After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g.- abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis)
  • Treatment:  Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia
  • Surgical management AVOIDED

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pre-term labor: This is unlikely, as in preterm labor, the pain isn’t acute severe. It will be increasing in intensity and frequency and occurring at regular intervals. Preterm labor is also associated with cervical dilatation and effacement

 

Option C. Torsion of Fibroid: This can happen in a pedunculated subserous fibroid but is quite a rare occurrence, It will be additionally associated with vomiting and will require surgical management

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid during pregnancy presents with acute severe pain, and symptomatic treatment is the primary approach, avoiding surgical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 275, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What would be the mode of delivery in images 1 and 2? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image 1: Vaginal; image 2: Cesarean

 

In the provided images, the presentation of the twins is crucial in determining the mode of delivery:

 

  • Image 1: Both twins are in a cephalic presentation (head down), making it safe to consider vaginal delivery. Twin pregnancies where both twins present cephalically are usually managed vaginally unless there are other contraindications.
  • Image 2: The first twin (Twin A or the lowermost baby) is in a breech presentation, while the second twin is cephalic. In this scenario, a cesarean section is preferred to avoid complications associated with breech delivery, such as cord prolapse or head entrapment. Therefore, cesarean delivery is the recommended mode for this presentation.

 

Indications for cesarean in twin pregnancy:

 

  1. First twin is non-cephalic (breech or transverse presentation).
  2. Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins: Elective LSCS at around 34 weeks.
  3. Conjoined twins.
  4. Higher-order multiples (triplets, quadruplets, or more).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In twin pregnancies, the mode of delivery is determined primarily by the presentation of the first twin. If the first twin is cephalic, vaginal delivery can be considered, but if the first twin is non-cephalic (e.g., breech), a cesarean section is generally recommended.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2A1 at 18 weeks of gestation came with complaints of draining PV for the past 4 hours. On examination, membranes are ruptured, and uterine contractions present. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a short cervix <25 mm and funneling of internal os >1 cm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical incompetence

 

  • Cervical incompetence: Cervical incompetence (or insufficiency) is characterized by features of a short cervix (<25 mm) and funneling of the internal os (>1 cm). This condition typically presents with a history of recurrent painless mid-trimester abortions. In this case, the patient presents with draining PV, ruptured membranes, and uterine contractions at 18 weeks gestation, which are indicative of cervical incompetence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and is accompanied by painless profuse vaginal bleeding. This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix. However, it is not characterized by a short cervix or funneling of the internal os, which rules it out in this scenario.

 

Option C. Abruptio placenta: Abruptio placenta refers to the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It may be revealed or concealed and characteristically shows a tonically contracted uterus. It presents with painful vaginal bleeding, which is different from the symptoms of cervical incompetence.

 

Option D. Traumatic injury: Traumatic injury can cause bleeding and other symptoms, but it is not typically associated with a short cervix and funneling of the internal os, as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cervical incompetence is characterized by a short cervix (<25 mm) and funneling of the internal os (>1 cm) on transvaginal ultrasound, often leading to painless mid-trimester abortions.

  

 Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 197-198

choices.text: Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The optimal time for determining the type of twin pregnancy through ultrasound is between 11+0 to 13+6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 45 to 84 mm. This period allows for the most accurate dating and assessment of chorionicity, which is crucial for the management and outcome of twin pregnancies.

 

  • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion.
    • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
    • Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best time to determine the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

The treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially caused by Plasmodium vivax, requires special consideration due to the potential effects on both the mother and the fetus. The key points are:

 

  • Chloroquine: Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women. It is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Alternative Drugs: If there is resistance to chloroquine, quinine can be used as a secondary option.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum malaria, artesunate is the preferred drug, followed by quinine, both of which can be safely used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: This combination is not used in pregnancy due to the contraindication of primaquine. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially in those with G6PD deficiency. It is not used for radical cure in pregnant women and is deferred until after delivery.

 

Option C. Quinine: While quinine can be used if there is resistance to chloroquine, it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax.

 

Option D. Artesunate: Artesunate is the drug of choice for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but not for Plasmodium vivax in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

 

  • Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler
Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A medical intern is observing an ultrasound for a patient with Rh isoimmunization. Which parameter is used to determine fetal anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raised PSV on MCA Doppler

 

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) is the gold standard non-invasive test for detecting fetal anemia. In fetal anemia, there is increased cardiac output and reduced blood viscosity, leading to faster blood flow. This results in increased PSV in the middle cerebral artery. A PSV value >1.5 MoM (Multiples of Median) for gestational age suggests significant fetal anemia and may indicate the need for further evaluation or intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced PSV on MCA Doppler: Incorrect because fetal anemia causes increased, not decreased, blood flow velocity in the MCA due to compensatory mechanisms.

 

Option C. Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: While umbilical artery Doppler is useful for assessing placental function and fetal well-being, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing fetal anemia. Changes in umbilical artery flow are more indicative of placental resistance.

 

Option D. Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: This finding is more associated with placental insufficiency and does not specifically indicate fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Increased Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler is the key non-invasive indicator of fetal anemia.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Twin pregnancy where 1 twin is older by 1 month than the other on ultrasound. What is this known as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfetation


Superfetation is the phenomenon where two ova are released in separate menstrual cycles and are fertilized at different times, leading to the conception of twins with different gestational ages. This means that one twin is conceived at a later date than the other, which can result in an observable difference in size or developmental stage on ultrasound. Although superfetation is documented in some animals, it is extremely rare and largely theoretical in humans due to the cessation of ovulation after the first conception. Nonetheless, it is the best explanation for the scenario where one twin appears to be older by a month than the other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova released in the same menstrual cycle are fertilized by separate acts of intercourse. The twins conceived have the same gestational age, although they may vary slightly in size. This phenomenon does not explain a one-month difference in age between twins.

 

Option C. Illegitimate: This term is not a medical explanation related to twin pregnancies. It refers to a non-scientific or socially defined concept and does not pertain to any biological condition involving twins.

 

Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic: This refers to twins that share both the chorion and the amniotic sac, resulting from the splitting of a single fertilized egg. These twins are identical and have the same gestational age; they do not account for any significant size or age discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Superfetation refers to a rare phenomenon where twins are conceived at different times, resulting in a significant difference in gestational ages, although it is mostly theoretical in humans.
